page.title: 07HOUSING
page.content: Housing has spread along the valleys and more recently up the slopes. the older houses in the Conservation Area are constructed of sarsen, chalk and flint with tiles or slates. Most houses are of brick with blocks in recent construction. Older houses make some 50% of the total, mostly terraced or semi-detached. Some houses are still thatched and there are 3 or 4 traditional houses in their own grounds. The housing stock has increased by about one third recently with 42 built in the 1950s, 101 in the 1960s and 55 in the 1970s. Building continues as 'in-fill' at both the expensive and starter ends of the market. There are some 107 council built houses, some of which are now owner occupied, including flats and bungalows for elderly people in the Whitley area
